Here are a few high‑impact angles I can run right away:

- Sales trends over time: I’ll chart monthly revenue and orders and compare vs the prior period to spot growth or slowdowns.
- Product performance: I’ll rank products and categories by revenue and margin proxy (unit price × quantity) to identify best sellers and laggards.
- Customer behavior: I’ll split new vs repeat buyers and compare orders and revenue by city to find high‑value segments.
- Basket insights: I’ll surface product pairs frequently bought together to inform bundles and cross‑sell.

Want me to start with a quick sales overview (monthly trend, top products, top cities) and then drill down, or is there a different focus you’d prefer?
you take the wheel

function.arguments:
{"title": "Monthly trend", "sql": "SELECT strftime('%Y-%m', order_date) AS month,
       COUNT(id) AS orders,
       ROUND(SUM(total), 2) AS revenue
FROM orders
GROUP BY month
ORDER BY month
LIMIT 100;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Top products", "sql": "SELECT p.name AS product,
       SUM(oi.quantity) AS units,
       ROUND(SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price), 2) AS revenue,
       COUNT(DISTINCT oi.order_id) AS orders
FROM order_items oi
JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id
GROUP BY p.name
ORDER BY revenue DESC, units DESC
LIMIT 20;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Top categories", "sql": "SELECT COALESCE(p.category, 'Uncategorized') AS category,
       SUM(oi.quantity) AS units,
       ROUND(SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price), 2) AS revenue,
       ROUND(AVG(oi.unit_price), 2) AS avg_price
FROM order_items oi
JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id
GROUP BY COALESCE(p.category, 'Uncategorized')
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 20;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Top cities", "sql": "SELECT COALESCE(c.city, 'Unknown') AS city,
       COUNT(o.id) AS orders,
       ROUND(SUM(o.total), 2) AS revenue
FROM orders o
JOIN customers c ON o.customer_id = c.id
GROUP BY COALESCE(c.city, 'Unknown')
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 20;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "New vs repeat split", "sql": "WITH first_dates AS (
  SELECT customer_id, MIN(order_date) AS first_date
  FROM orders
  GROUP BY customer_id
)
SELECT CASE WHEN o.order_date = f.first_date THEN 'first' ELSE 'repeat' END AS segment,
       COUNT(o.id) AS orders,
       ROUND(SUM(o.total), 2) AS revenue
FROM orders o
JOIN first_dates f ON o.customer_id = f.customer_id
GROUP BY segment
ORDER BY segment;
", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Top product pairs", "sql": "SELECT p1.name AS product_a,
       p2.name AS product_b,
       COUNT(*) AS orders_together
FROM order_items oi1
JOIN order_items oi2
  ON oi1.order_id = oi2.order_id
 AND oi1.product_id < oi2.product_id
JOIN products p1 ON oi1.product_id = p1.id
JOIN products p2 ON oi2.product_id = p2.id
GROUP BY p1.name, p2.name
ORDER BY orders_together DESC
LIMIT 20;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Top customers", "sql": "SELECT c.name AS customer,
       COALESCE(c.city, 'Unknown') AS city,
       COUNT(o.id) AS orders,
       ROUND(SUM(o.total), 2) AS revenue
FROM orders o
JOIN customers c ON o.customer_id = c.id
GROUP BY c.name, COALESCE(c.city, 'Unknown')
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 20;", "max_rows": 100}

- Revenue is lumpy month to month, with a recent high in Jan 2025 and steady recovery since March.
- Top products are Rapid License and Aero Module; Gadgets and Hardware lead category revenue.
- Chicago, San Francisco, and Atlanta are the biggest revenue cities; repeat buyers drive ~87% of sales.
- Common bundles include Nano Module with Ultra License and Aqua Gizmo with Eco Device—ripe for cross‑sell offers.

function.arguments:
{"title":"Product performance (last 30d)","sql":"WITH
  latest AS (
    SELECT MAX(order_date) AS max_date FROM orders
  ),
  window AS (
    SELECT date(max_date, '-29 days') AS start_date, max_date AS end_date FROM latest
  ),
  sales_window AS (
    SELECT
      p.name AS product,
      p.category AS category,
      oi.order_id,
      o.order_date,
      oi.quantity,
      oi.unit_price,
      (oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS line_revenue
    FROM order_items oi
    JOIN orders o ON oi.order_id = o.id
    JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id
    JOIN window w
    WHERE o.order_date BETWEEN w.start_date AND w.end_date
  ),
  totals AS (
    SELECT SUM(line_revenue) AS total_revenue FROM sales_window
  )
SELECT
  sw.product AS product,
  sw.category AS category,
  COUNT(DISTINCT sw.order_id) AS orders,
  SUM(sw.quantity) AS units,
  ROUND(SUM(sw.line_revenue), 2) AS revenue,
  ROUND(SUM(sw.line_revenue) / NULLIF(SUM(sw.quantity), 0), 2) AS avg_price,
  ROUND(100.0 * SUM(sw.line_revenue) / NULLIF(t.total_revenue, 0), 2) AS revenue_share_pct
FROM sales_window sw
CROSS JOIN totals t
GROUP BY sw.product, sw.category
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 100;","max_rows":100}
function.name: sql_query

{"title": "Monthly sales trend", "sql": "SELECT strftime('%Y-%m', orders.order_date) AS month, COUNT(orders.id) AS orders, SUM(orders.total) AS revenue, ROUND(SUM(orders.total)/COUNT(orders.id), 2) AS aov
FROM orders
GROUP BY month
ORDER BY month ASC
LIMIT 24;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Revenue by category", "sql": "SELECT products.category AS category,
       SUM(order_items.quantity * order_items.unit_price) AS revenue,
       SUM(order_items.quantity) AS units
FROM order_items
JOIN products ON order_items.product_id = products.id
GROUP BY products.category
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 10;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Top products by revenue", "sql": "SELECT products.name AS product,
       products.category AS category,
       SUM(order_items.quantity * order_items.unit_price) AS revenue,
       SUM(order_items.quantity) AS units
FROM order_items
JOIN products ON order_items.product_id = products.id
GROUP BY products.id, products.name, products.category
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 10;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Top customers by revenue", "sql": "SELECT customers.name AS customer,
       customers.city AS city,
       COUNT(orders.id) AS orders,
       SUM(orders.total) AS revenue
FROM orders
JOIN customers ON orders.customer_id = customers.id
GROUP BY customers.id, customers.name, customers.city
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 10;", "max_rows": 100}

function.arguments:
{"title": "Orders by city", "sql": "SELECT customers.city AS city,
       COUNT(orders.id) AS orders,
       SUM(orders.total) AS revenue
FROM orders
JOIN customers ON orders.customer_id = customers.id
GROUP BY customers.city
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 10;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Repeat purchase rate", "sql": "WITH customer_orders AS (
  SELECT customers.id AS id,
         customers.name AS name,
         COUNT(orders.id) AS orders
  FROM customers
  LEFT JOIN orders ON orders.customer_id = customers.id
  GROUP BY customers.id, customers.name
)
SELECT SUM(CASE WHEN orders >= 1 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) AS buyers,
       SUM(CASE WHEN orders >= 2 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) AS repeat_buyers,
       ROUND(100.0 * SUM(CASE WHEN orders >= 2 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) / NULLIF(SUM(CASE WHEN orders >= 1 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END), 0), 1) AS repeat_rate_pct
FROM customer_orders;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Avg items per order", "sql": "SELECT ROUND(AVG(item_count), 2) AS avg_items_per_order
FROM (
  SELECT order_items.order_id AS order_id,
         SUM(order_items.quantity) AS item_count
  FROM order_items
  GROUP BY order_items.order_id
);", "max_rows": 100}

FROM customers
GROUP BY month
ORDER BY month ASC
LIMIT 24;", "max_rows": 100}

{"title":"Revenue by category","sql":"SELECT COALESCE(p.category, 'Unknown') AS category, SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue
FROM order_items oi
JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id
GROUP BY COALESCE(p.category, 'Unknown')
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 100;","max_rows":100}
function.name: sql_query

{"title": "Monthly sales trend", "sql": "SELECT strftime('%Y-%m', order_date) AS month,
       COUNT(*) AS orders,
       SUM(total) AS revenue,
       AVG(total) AS avg_order_value
FROM orders
GROUP BY month
ORDER BY month
LIMIT 100;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Revenue by category", "sql": "SELECT COALESCE(products.category, 'Uncategorized') AS category,
       SUM(order_items.quantity * order_items.unit_price) AS revenue,
       SUM(order_items.quantity) AS units
FROM order_items
JOIN products ON order_items.product_id = products.id
GROUP BY category
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 10;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Top products by revenue", "sql": "SELECT products.name AS product,
       SUM(order_items.quantity * order_items.unit_price) AS revenue,
       SUM(order_items.quantity) AS units
FROM order_items
JOIN products ON order_items.product_id = products.id
GROUP BY product
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 10;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Top cities by revenue", "sql": "SELECT COALESCE(customers.city, 'Unknown') AS city,
       COUNT(*) AS orders,
       SUM(orders.total) AS revenue
FROM orders
JOIN customers ON orders.customer_id = customers.id
GROUP BY city
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 10;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Monthly new customers", "sql": "SELECT strftime('%Y-%m', signup_date) AS month,
       COUNT(*) AS new_customers
FROM customers
GROUP BY month
ORDER BY month
LIMIT 100;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Repeat purchase rate", "sql": "WITH order_counts AS (
  SELECT customer_id, COUNT(*) AS orders
  FROM orders
  GROUP BY customer_id
)
SELECT
  SUM(CASE WHEN orders >= 2 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) AS repeat_customers,
  SUM(CASE WHEN orders >= 1 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) AS ordering_customers,
  AVG(orders) AS avg_orders_per_customer
FROM order_counts;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

Here are quick, high-impact insights from the dataset:

- Revenue trend: Revenue has generally grown into 2025, peaking in Jan 2025, with dips in Feb and Apr–Jun.

```chart
{"title":"Revenue by month","type":"line","x":"month","y":"revenue","columns":["month","revenue"],"rows":[["2024-01",13837.039999999999],["2024-02",8713.08],["2024-03",11866.560000000001],["2024-04",10708.419999999998],["2024-05",8818.66],["2024-06",9280.37],["2024-07",9674.95],["2024-08",11782.81],["2024-09",8070.340000000001],["2024-10",12768.439999999997],["2024-11",12774.170000000002],["2024-12",12687.349999999999],["2025-01",17546.29],["2025-02",8135.21],["2025-03",13861.640000000001],["2025-04",10096.22],["2025-05",12293.449999999999],["2025-06",10212.94]]}
```

- Category mix: Gadgets and Hardware lead revenue; Accessories is smallest and highly unit-driven.

```chart
{"title":"Revenue by category","type":"bar","x":"category","y":"revenue","columns":["category","revenue"],"rows":[["Gadgets",46568.82999999999],["Hardware",44092.330000000016],["Services",39166.43999999998],["Software",32837.81000000003],["Apparel",25642.039999999994],["Accessories",14820.489999999993]]}
```

- Product winners: Rapid License and Aero Module top revenue; Fusion Bundle is high-revenue with low volume (premium).

```chart
{"title":"Top products by revenue","type":"bar","x":"product","y":"revenue","columns":["product","revenue"],"rows":[["Rapid License",15043.72],["Aero Module",14499.920000000002],["Aqua Gizmo",12421.81],["Fusion Bundle",11723.810000000001],["Quantum Panel",11607.740000000002],["Max Widget",9933.779999999999],["Max Subscription",9320.99],["Nano Module",8839.45],["Lite Module",8519.85],["Smart Panel",8107.61]]}
```

- Geographic hotspots: Chicago, San Francisco, and Atlanta are the top three cities by revenue.

```chart
{"title":"Top cities by revenue","type":"bar","x":"city","y":"revenue","columns":["city","revenue"],"rows":[["Chicago",30649.40999999999],["San Francisco",26753.609999999993],["Atlanta",26084.629999999994],["Seattle",23538.030000000006],["Miami",22888.85000000001],["New York",20230.049999999996],["Boston",16973.69],["Austin",13964.560000000003],["Denver",11931.99],["Los Angeles",10113.12]]}
```

- Customer base: New customer additions are modest and spiky; the customer file shows everyone who’s ordered has repeated (very high repeat rate).

```chart
{"title":"New customers by month","type":"line","x":"month","y":"new_customers","columns":["month","new_customers"],"rows":[["2023-01",3],["2023-02",2],["2023-03",4],["2023-04",5],["2023-05",2],["2023-06",3],["2023-07",1],["2023-08",4],["2023-09",2],["2023-10",4],["2024-01",3],["2024-02",2],["2024-03",2],["2024-04",1],["2024-06",3],["2024-07",1],["2024-08",3],["2024-09",5],["2024-10",5],["2024-11",1],["2024-12",4]]}
```

Next steps I can run:
- Diagnose the Feb–Jun 2025 dip by product and city (to identify what fell).
- Build a simple cohort view to quantify retention and time-to-repeat.
- Surface cross-sell bundles: which product pairs co-occur most in orders.
- Identify underperforming cities/categories with high units but low revenue to target pricing or upsell.

function.arguments:
{"title":"Repeat purchase rate","sql":"WITH first_orders AS (
  SELECT customer_id, MIN(order_date) AS first_date
  FROM orders
  GROUP BY customer_id
), orders_by_customer AS (
  SELECT customer_id, COUNT(*) AS orders
  FROM orders
  GROUP BY customer_id
)
SELECT 
  SUM(CASE WHEN o.orders >= 2 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END) * 1.0 / COUNT(*) AS repeat_purchase_rate,
  AVG(o.orders) AS avg_orders_per_customer
FROM orders_by_customer o;","max_rows":100}

Here's a concise, insight‑driven readout of your commerce data (Jan 2024–Jun 2025).

Executive snapshot
- Revenue: 203,127.94 across 500 orders; average order value: 406.26; active customers: 60.
- Customer behavior: 100% are repeat buyers; average 8.3 orders per customer.
- Best month: Jan 2025 (17,546); Jan 2025 vs Jan 2024 is up ~27%.

Growth and seasonality

```chart
{
  "title": "Monthly revenue trend",
  "type": "line",
  "x": "month",
  "y": "revenue",
  "columns": ["month", "revenue"],
  "rows": [
    ["2024-01", 13837.04],
    ["2024-02", 8713.08],
    ["2024-03", 11866.56],
    ["2024-04", 10708.42],
    ["2024-05", 8818.66],
    ["2024-06", 9280.37],
    ["2024-07", 9674.95],
    ["2024-08", 11782.81],
    ["2024-09", 8070.34],
    ["2024-10", 12768.44],
    ["2024-11", 12774.17],
    ["2024-12", 12687.35],
    ["2025-01", 17546.29],
    ["2025-02", 8135.21],
    ["2025-03", 13861.64],
    ["2025-04", 10096.22],
    ["2025-05", 12293.45],
    ["2025-06", 10212.94]
  ]
}
```

What sells
- Category leaders by revenue: Gadgets (46.6k), Hardware (44.1k), Services (39.2k). Accessories is smallest despite the highest unit count—suggests low price points.
- Top product: Rapid License (Gadgets) at 15.0k revenue; next are Aero Module (Services) 13.3k and Fusion Bundle (Hardware) 11.7k.

```chart
{
  "title": "Revenue by category",
  "type": "bar",
  "x": "category",
  "y": "revenue",
  "columns": ["category", "revenue"],
  "rows": [
    ["Gadgets", 46568.83],
    ["Hardware", 44092.33],
    ["Services", 39166.44],
    ["Software", 32837.81],
    ["Apparel", 25642.04],
    ["Accessories", 14820.49]
  ]
}
```

Where demand is
- Top cities by revenue: Chicago (30.6k), San Francisco (26.8k), Atlanta (26.1k). Chicago also leads in order count (77), indicating both scale and depth of demand.

```chart
{
  "title": "Revenue by city (top 10)",
  "type": "bar",
  "x": "city",
  "y": "revenue",
  "columns": ["city", "revenue"],
  "rows": [
    ["Chicago", 30649.41],
    ["San Francisco", 26753.61],
    ["Atlanta", 26084.63],
    ["Seattle", 23538.03],
    ["Miami", 22888.85],
    ["New York", 20230.05],
    ["Boston", 16973.69],
    ["Austin", 13964.56],
    ["Denver", 11931.99],
    ["Los Angeles", 10113.12]
  ]
}
```

Customer highlights
- Most valuable customers: Victor Thomas (Atlanta, 6.58k), Uma Jones (Atlanta, 5.76k), Carol Taylor (Austin, 5.64k). Atlanta concentrates high-value buyers despite Chicago leading overall revenue.

Suggested next steps
- Cohorts and retention: I’ll measure first-time vs repeat behavior by signup month to spot any softening in newer cohorts.
- Product-city fit: I’ll map category revenue by city to find the best matches for targeted campaigns.
- Price/mix drivers: I’ll decompose revenue into price vs volume by category to explain Accessories’ low revenue share.
- Seasonality plan: I’ll compare Q1 vs Q2 year-over-year to size recurring spikes and plan inventory/campaigns.

In the last 18 months, revenue totaled 203k with strong Jan–Mar peaks, Gadgets leading category sales, Chicago driving the most revenue, and a fully repeat customer base.

{"title":"City sales (last 6 months)","sql":"WITH maxd AS (
  SELECT DATE(MAX(order_date)) AS max_date FROM orders
), window AS (
  SELECT DATE(strftime('%Y-%m-01', max_date)) AS month_start FROM maxd
), filtered AS (
  SELECT o.id, o.total, o.order_date, c.city
  FROM orders o
  JOIN customers c ON c.id = o.customer_id
  WHERE o.order_date >= DATE((SELECT month_start FROM window), '-5 months')
)
SELECT city AS city,
       COUNT(id) AS orders,
       ROUND(SUM(total), 2) AS revenue,
       ROUND(AVG(total), 2) AS aov
FROM filtered
GROUP BY city
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 20;","max_rows":100}

function.arguments:
{"title": "Monthly sales trend", "sql": "SELECT strftime('%Y-%m', orders.order_date) AS month,
       ROUND(SUM(orders.total), 2) AS revenue,
       COUNT(orders.id) AS orders
FROM orders
GROUP BY month
ORDER BY month
LIMIT 100;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Top products by revenue", "sql": "SELECT products.name AS product,
       products.category AS category,
       ROUND(SUM(order_items.quantity * order_items.unit_price), 2) AS revenue,
       SUM(order_items.quantity) AS units
FROM order_items
JOIN products ON order_items.product_id = products.id
GROUP BY products.name, products.category
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 10;", "max_rows": 100}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "New vs repeat revenue", "sql": "WITH first_orders AS (
  SELECT orders.customer_id AS customer_id,
         MIN(orders.order_date) AS first_date
  FROM orders
  GROUP BY orders.customer_id
),
orders_labeled AS (
  SELECT orders.order_date AS order_date,
         orders.total AS total,
         CASE WHEN orders.order_date = first_orders.first_date THEN 1 ELSE 0 END AS is_new
  FROM orders
  JOIN first_orders ON orders.customer_id = first_orders.customer_id
)
SELECT strftime('%Y-%m', orders_labeled.order_date) AS month,
       ROUND(SUM(CASE WHEN orders_labeled.is_new = 1 THEN orders_labeled.total ELSE 0 END), 2) AS new_revenue,
       ROUND(SUM(CASE WHEN orders_labeled.is_new = 0 THEN orders_labeled.total ELSE 0 END), 2) AS repeat_revenue
FROM orders_labeled
GROUP BY month
ORDER BY month
LIMIT 100;", "max_rows": 100}

function.arguments:
{"title": "Top customers by revenue", "sql": "WITH total_rev AS (
  SELECT SUM(orders.total) AS total_rev
  FROM orders
)
SELECT customers.name AS customer,
       customers.city AS city,
       ROUND(SUM(orders.total), 2) AS revenue,
       ROUND(100.0 * SUM(orders.total) / (SELECT total_rev FROM total_rev), 1) AS share_pct,
       COUNT(orders.id) AS orders
FROM orders
JOIN customers ON orders.customer_id = customers.id
GROUP BY customers.name, customers.city
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 10;", "max_rows": 100}

{"title":"30-day product summary","sql":"SELECT 
  ROUND(SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price), 2) AS revenue,
  COUNT(DISTINCT o.id) AS orders,
  SUM(oi.quantity) AS units,
  ROUND(SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) / NULLIF(COUNT(DISTINCT o.id),0), 2) AS avg_order_value,
  ROUND(SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) / NULLIF(SUM(oi.quantity),0), 2) AS avg_selling_price
FROM order_items oi
JOIN orders o ON oi.order_id = o.id
WHERE DATE(o.order_date) >= DATE('now','-30 day');","max_rows":100}

function.arguments:
{"title":"Top products (90 days)","sql":"WITH bounds AS (
  SELECT DATE(MAX(order_date)) AS end_date,
         DATE(MAX(order_date), '-90 day') AS start_date
  FROM orders
)
SELECT 
  p.name AS product,
  p.category AS category,
  SUM(oi.quantity) AS units,
  ROUND(SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price), 2) AS revenue,
  COUNT(DISTINCT oi.order_id) AS orders,
  ROUND(SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) / NULLIF(SUM(oi.quantity),0), 2) AS asp
FROM order_items oi
JOIN orders o ON oi.order_id = o.id
JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id
JOIN bounds b
WHERE DATE(o.order_date) BETWEEN b.start_date AND b.end_date
GROUP BY p.id, p.name, p.category
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 10;","max_rows":100}

function.arguments:
{"title":"Trend by week (90 days)","sql":"WITH bounds AS (
  SELECT DATE(MAX(order_date)) AS end_date,
         DATE(MAX(order_date), '-90 day') AS start_date
  FROM orders
)
SELECT 
  STRFTIME('%Y-%W', DATE(o.order_date)) AS week,
  ROUND(SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price), 2) AS revenue,
  SUM(oi.quantity) AS units,
  COUNT(DISTINCT o.id) AS orders
FROM order_items oi
JOIN orders o ON oi.order_id = o.id
JOIN bounds b
WHERE DATE(o.order_date) BETWEEN b.start_date AND b.end_date
GROUP BY STRFTIME('%Y-%W', DATE(o.order_date))
ORDER BY week ASC
LIMIT 100;","max_rows":100}

function.arguments:
{"title":"Overall 90d summary","sql":"WITH params AS (
  SELECT MAX(order_date) AS max_date FROM orders
), last90 AS (
  SELECT 
    SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue,
    SUM(oi.quantity) AS units,
    COUNT(DISTINCT oi.product_id) AS products
  FROM orders o
  JOIN order_items oi ON oi.order_id = o.id
  WHERE o.order_date > date((SELECT max_date FROM params), '-90 days')
    AND o.order_date <= (SELECT max_date FROM params)
), prev90 AS (
  SELECT 
    SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue,
    SUM(oi.quantity) AS units,
    COUNT(DISTINCT oi.product_id) AS products
  FROM orders o
  JOIN order_items oi ON oi.order_id = o.id
  WHERE o.order_date > date((SELECT max_date FROM params), '-180 days')
    AND o.order_date <= date((SELECT max_date FROM params), '-90 days')
)
SELECT 
  l.revenue AS revenue_90d,
  l.units AS units_90d,
  l.products AS products_90d,
  p.revenue AS revenue_prev90d,
  p.units AS units_prev90d,
  p.products AS products_prev90d
FROM last90 l, prev90 p;
","max_rows":100}

function.arguments:
{"title":"Revenue by product","sql":"WITH params AS (
  SELECT MAX(order_date) AS max_date FROM orders
)
SELECT 
  p.name AS product,
  p.category AS category,
  SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue,
  SUM(oi.quantity) AS units
FROM orders o
JOIN order_items oi ON oi.order_id = o.id
JOIN products p ON p.id = oi.product_id
WHERE o.order_date > date((SELECT max_date FROM params), '-90 days')
  AND o.order_date <= (SELECT max_date FROM params)
GROUP BY p.name, p.category
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 20;","max_rows":100}

function.arguments:
{"title":"Top products trend","sql":"WITH params AS (
  SELECT MAX(order_date) AS max_date FROM orders
), top_products AS (
  SELECT p.id, p.name
  FROM orders o
  JOIN order_items oi ON oi.order_id = o.id
  JOIN products p ON p.id = oi.product_id
  WHERE o.order_date > date((SELECT max_date FROM params), '-90 days')
    AND o.order_date <= (SELECT max_date FROM params)
  GROUP BY p.id, p.name
  ORDER BY SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) DESC
  LIMIT 5
)
SELECT 
  date(o.order_date) AS date,
  tp.name AS product,
  SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue
FROM orders o
JOIN order_items oi ON oi.order_id = o.id
JOIN top_products tp ON tp.id = oi.product_id
WHERE o.order_date > date((SELECT max_date FROM params), '-90 days')
  AND o.order_date <= (SELECT max_date FROM params)
GROUP BY date(o.order_date), tp.name
ORDER BY date(o.order_date) ASC
LIMIT 500;","max_rows":500}

function.arguments:
{"title":"Product momentum","sql":"WITH params AS (
  SELECT MAX(order_date) AS max_date FROM orders
), periods AS (
  SELECT date((SELECT max_date FROM params), '-90 days') AS start_90,
         (SELECT max_date FROM params) AS end_90,
         date((SELECT max_date FROM params), '-180 days') AS start_prev,
         date((SELECT max_date FROM params), '-90 days') AS end_prev
), curr AS (
  SELECT p.name AS product,
         SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue
  FROM orders o
  JOIN order_items oi ON oi.order_id = o.id
  JOIN products p ON p.id = oi.product_id
  WHERE o.order_date > (SELECT start_90 FROM periods)
    AND o.order_date <= (SELECT end_90 FROM periods)
  GROUP BY p.name
), prev AS (
  SELECT p.name AS product,
         SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue
  FROM orders o
  JOIN order_items oi ON oi.order_id = o.id
  JOIN products p ON p.id = oi.product_id
  WHERE o.order_date > (SELECT start_prev FROM periods)
    AND o.order_date <= (SELECT end_prev FROM periods)
  GROUP BY p.name
)
SELECT 
  c.product AS product,
  c.revenue AS revenue_90d,
  p.revenue AS revenue_prev90d,
  (c.revenue - IFNULL(p.revenue,0)) AS delta
FROM curr c
LEFT JOIN prev p ON p.product = c.product
ORDER BY delta DESC
LIMIT 15;","max_rows":100}

  JOIN products p ON p.id = oi.product_id
  WHERE o.order_date > (SELECT start_90 FROM periods)

), prev AS (
  SELECT p.name AS product,
         SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue

Product performance report (last 90 days, ending 2025-06-28; compared to prior 90 days)

Summary
- Revenue was 32,602.61 in the last 90 days, down 18% vs prior period (39,771.10). Units were 483 (-19% vs 597). Products sold: 49 vs 50 prior. Mix shifts and weaker volumes drove the decline. Executive takeaway: we’re selling slightly fewer products to fewer buyers at lower total value.

Top products (revenue, 90 days)
- Leaders: Fusion Bundle, Max Subscription, Quantum Panel, Rapid License, and Lite Module. These five account for a large share of revenue and show episodic bursts rather than steady daily sales.

Category mix
- Hardware and Gadgets lead, generating just over half of total revenue combined, followed by Software and Services. Apparel and Accessories contribute meaningfully via units but at lower price points.

Momentum vs prior 90 days
- Gaining traction: Quantum Panel, Fusion Bundle, Pro Sensor, and Max Subscription showed the strongest growth vs the prior period.
- Losing ground: Aero Module, Nano Module, Lite Module, and Max Widget declined meaningfully versus the prior period, suggesting potential cannibalization or reduced demand.

Next steps
- I can drill into price vs. units for top products to separate demand from pricing effects.
- I can segment performance by category and city to spot geographic opportunities.
- I can analyze repeat purchasing on subscriptions vs one-off items to stabilize revenue.
- I can run a promo impact check around early-May spikes to inform future campaigns.

Executive takeaway: Revenue is down 18% over the last 90 days, led by strength in Fusion Bundle and Max Subscription but offset by notable declines in several Modules—focusing on category leaders and addressing Module weakness should stabilize growth.

function.arguments:
{"title":"Top5 price-unit splits","sql":"WITH params AS (
  SELECT MAX(order_date) AS max_date FROM orders
), periods AS (
  SELECT date((SELECT max_date FROM params), '-90 days') AS start_90,
         (SELECT max_date FROM params) AS end_90,
         date((SELECT max_date FROM params), '-180 days') AS start_prev,
         date((SELECT max_date FROM params), '-90 days') AS end_prev
), top5 AS (
  SELECT p.id, p.name
  FROM orders o
  JOIN order_items oi ON oi.order_id = o.id
  JOIN products p ON p.id = oi.product_id
  WHERE o.order_date > (SELECT start_90 FROM periods)
    AND o.order_date <= (SELECT end_90 FROM periods)
  GROUP BY p.id, p.name
  ORDER BY SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) DESC
  LIMIT 5
), agg AS (
  SELECT 
    p.name AS product,
    'Last 90d' AS period,
    SUM(oi.quantity) AS units,
    SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue,
    SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) * 1.0 / SUM(oi.quantity) AS asp
  FROM orders o
  JOIN order_items oi ON oi.order_id = o.id
  JOIN products p ON p.id = oi.product_id
  WHERE o.order_date > (SELECT start_90 FROM periods)
    AND o.order_date <= (SELECT end_90 FROM periods)
    AND p.id IN (SELECT id FROM top5)
  GROUP BY p.name
  UNION ALL
  SELECT 
    p.name AS product,
    'Prior 90d' AS period,
    SUM(oi.quantity) AS units,
    SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue,
    SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) * 1.0 / SUM(oi.quantity) AS asp
  FROM orders o
  JOIN order_items oi ON oi.order_id = o.id
  JOIN products p ON p.id = oi.product_id
  WHERE o.order_date > (SELECT start_prev FROM periods)
    AND o.order_date <= (SELECT end_prev FROM periods)
    AND p.id IN (SELECT id FROM top5)
  GROUP BY p.name
)
SELECT product, period, units, ROUND(asp, 2) AS asp, ROUND(revenue,2) AS revenue
FROM agg
ORDER BY product, period DESC
LIMIT 20;","max_rows":100}

Here’s a quick demand vs. price read for the top 5 products (last 90 days vs prior). Units proxy demand; ASP is average selling price.

Key takeaways
- Fusion Bundle: Revenue growth driven by both higher units (9 → 11) and higher ASP (276 → 305). Positive price and volume.
- Max Subscription: Growth is volume-led (17 → 21) with flat ASP (~120). Demand strength, stable pricing.
- Quantum Panel: Growth driven by both more units (6 → 11) and a higher ASP (178 → 190). Improving mix/price.
- Lite Module: Decline is volume-driven (21 → 13) with flat-to-down ASP (~132 → 131). Demand softness.
- Aero Module: Decline is volume-driven (16 → 7) with stable ASP (~192). Likely demand/mix issue, not price.

  p.category AS category,
  ROUND(SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price), 2) AS revenue
FROM order_items oi
JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id
GROUP BY p.category
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 100;","max_rows":100}

function.arguments:
{"title": "Top products by revenue", "sql": "
SELECT 
  p.name AS product,
  p.category,
  SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue,
  SUM(oi.quantity) AS units_sold,
  COUNT(DISTINCT oi.order_id) AS orders
FROM order_items oi
JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id
GROUP BY p.id, p.name, p.category
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 15
"}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Category performance summary", "sql": "
SELECT 
  p.category,
  COUNT(DISTINCT p.id) AS products,
  SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue,
  SUM(oi.quantity) AS units_sold,
  COUNT(DISTINCT oi.order_id) AS orders
FROM order_items oi
JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id
GROUP BY p.category
ORDER BY revenue DESC
"}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Product velocity metrics", "sql": "
SELECT 
  p.name AS product,
  p.category,
  p.price AS list_price,
  ROUND(AVG(oi.unit_price), 2) AS avg_selling_price,
  ROUND(AVG(oi.quantity), 2) AS avg_order_quantity,
  SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue
FROM order_items oi
JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id
GROUP BY p.id, p.name, p.category, p.price
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 10
"}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Low performers check", "sql": "
SELECT 
  p.name AS product,
  p.category,
  COALESCE(SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price), 0) AS revenue,
  COALESCE(SUM(oi.quantity), 0) AS units_sold
FROM products p
LEFT JOIN order_items oi ON p.id = oi.product_id
GROUP BY p.id, p.name, p.category
ORDER BY revenue ASC
LIMIT 10
"}

## Product Performance Report

### Top revenue drivers
**Aero Module** (Services) leads with $13.3K in revenue across 34 orders, followed by **Fusion Bundle** (Hardware, $11.7K) and **Quantum Panel** (Hardware, $10.2K). The top 15 products span multiple categories, with Services and Hardware dominating the upper tier. Average order quantities range from 1.8 to 2.1 units, indicating consistent single-purchase behavior across top performers.

```chart
{
  "title": "Top products by revenue",
  "type": "bar",
  "x": "product",
  "y": "revenue",
  "columns": ["product", "category", "revenue", "units_sold", "orders"],
  "rows": [["Aero Module", "Services", 13269.38, 69, 34], ["Fusion Bundle", "Hardware", 11723.81, 40, 18], ["Quantum Panel", "Hardware", 10231.93, 56, 26], ["Max Widget", "Services", 9933.78, 72, 33], ["Max Subscription", "Gadgets", 9320.99, 78, 38], ["Lite Module", "Hardware", 8519.85, 65, 29], ["Aqua Gizmo", "Software", 7887.38, 63, 30], ["Rapid License", "Gadgets", 7749.52, 70, 34], ["Rapid License", "Gadgets", 7294.20, 67, 35], ["Max Bundle", "Services", 6596.34, 46, 21], ["Hyper Sensor", "Software", 5598.73, 81, 38], ["Nano Module", "Services", 5336.84, 77, 35], ["Terra Kit", "Hardware", 5018.86, 61, 33], ["Nano Gizmo", "Gadgets", 4673.52, 53, 24], ["Eco Hub", "Apparel", 4628.27, 69, 34]]
}
```

### Category breakdown
**Gadgets** generates the highest revenue at $46.6K (12 products, 741 units sold), closely followed by **Hardware** ($44.1K, 6 products). Despite having only 5 products, **Services** delivers $39.2K, showing strong per-product efficiency. **Accessories** underperforms with $14.8K despite having 12 products and the highest unit volume (758), signaling low pricing or margin pressure.

```chart
{
  "title": "Revenue by category",
  "type": "bar",
  "x": "category",
  "y": "revenue",
  "columns": ["category", "products", "revenue", "units_sold", "orders"],
  "rows": [["Gadgets", 12, 46568.83, 741, 267], ["Hardware", 6, 44092.33, 304, 128], ["Services", 5, 39166.44, 336, 143], ["Software", 8, 32837.81, 473, 193], ["Apparel", 7, 25642.04, 433, 184], ["Accessories", 12, 14820.49, 758, 274]]
}
```

### Pricing and velocity
Top products maintain pricing discipline, with average selling prices closely tracking list prices (e.g., Aero Module sells at $192 vs. $190 list). Order quantities average around 2 units per transaction across all top performers, suggesting limited bulk purchasing. This consistency indicates stable demand without heavy discounting.

### Low performers
The bottom 10 products each generate under $1.3K in revenue, with **Max Gizmo** (Accessories) at just $369. Seven of these are Accessories, reinforcing the category's weak performance. These products account for minimal order volume and may be candidates for discontinuation or bundling strategies.

**Executive takeaway:** Gadgets and Hardware drive the portfolio with strong per-product efficiency, while Accessories drags performance despite high unit volume—consider pruning low performers and reallocating focus to Services and top-tier Gadgets.

function.arguments:
{"title": "Revenue by product category", "sql": "
SELECT 
  p.category AS category,
  ROUND(SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price), 2) AS revenue
FROM order_items oi
JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id
GROUP BY p.category
ORDER BY revenue DESC
"}

{"title": "Revenue trends over time", "sql": "
SELECT 
  strftime('%Y-%m', order_date) AS month,
  COUNT(DISTINCT id) AS orders,
  ROUND(SUM(total), 2) AS revenue
FROM orders
GROUP BY strftime('%Y-%m', order_date)
ORDER BY month
"}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Top products by revenue", "sql": "
SELECT 
  p.name AS product,
  p.category,
  SUM(oi.quantity) AS units_sold,
  ROUND(SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price), 2) AS revenue
FROM order_items oi
JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id
GROUP BY p.id, p.name, p.category
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 10
"}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Customer purchase patterns", "sql": "
SELECT 
  c.name AS customer,
  c.city,
  COUNT(o.id) AS orders,
  ROUND(SUM(o.total), 2) AS lifetime_value
FROM customers c
LEFT JOIN orders o ON c.id = o.customer_id
GROUP BY c.id, c.name, c.city
ORDER BY lifetime_value DESC
LIMIT 15
"}
function.name: sql_query

  p.category,
  COUNT(DISTINCT p.id) AS products,

  ROUND(SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price), 2) AS revenue

JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id

ORDER BY revenue DESC

function.arguments:
{"title": "Geographic revenue distribution", "sql": "
SELECT 
  c.city,
  COUNT(DISTINCT c.id) AS customers,
  COUNT(o.id) AS orders,
  ROUND(SUM(o.total), 2) AS revenue
FROM customers c
LEFT JOIN orders o ON c.id = o.customer_id
WHERE c.city IS NOT NULL
GROUP BY c.city
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 10
"}

## Revenue & Growth Trends

Your business shows **strong recent momentum**, with January 2025 hitting $17.5K revenue (43 orders), the highest month on record. The trend accelerated in late 2024 after a mid-year dip, suggesting successful seasonal campaigns or product launches. February 2025 dropped to $8.1K, but March rebounded to $13.9K, indicating typical monthly volatility.

## Product Performance

**Aero Module** (Services) dominates with $13.3K revenue from 69 units, followed by Fusion Bundle (Hardware, $11.7K) and Quantum Panel (Hardware, $10.2K). Your top 10 products span all major categories, showing a diversified portfolio. Services and Hardware items command higher unit prices and drive the most revenue per SKU.

## Category Breakdown

**Gadgets** leads with $46.6K (741 units sold), followed closely by Hardware ($44.1K, 304 units) and Services ($39.2K, 336 units). Accessories has the highest unit volume (758) but lowest revenue ($14.8K), indicating lower price points. Gadgets and Hardware are your revenue engines, while Accessories drives volume.

## Customer Insights

**Victor Thomas** (Atlanta) is your top customer with $6.6K lifetime value across 11 orders, followed by Uma Jones (Atlanta, $5.8K, 13 orders). Your top 15 customers average ~10 orders each, showing strong repeat behavior. Atlanta appears three times in the top seven, signaling a valuable geographic cluster.

## Geographic Distribution

**Chicago** leads all cities with $30.6K revenue (77 orders from 9 customers), followed by San Francisco ($26.8K, 65 orders) and Atlanta ($26.1K, 55 orders). function.arguments:
{"title": "Top products by revenue", "sql": "
SELECT 
  p.name AS product,
  p.category,
  SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue,
  SUM(oi.quantity) AS units_sold,
  COUNT(DISTINCT oi.order_id) AS orders
FROM order_items oi
JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id
GROUP BY p.id, p.name, p.category
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 15
"}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Revenue by category", "sql": "
SELECT 
  p.category,
  SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue,
  SUM(oi.quantity) AS units_sold,
  COUNT(DISTINCT oi.order_id) AS orders,
  COUNT(DISTINCT p.id) AS product_count
FROM order_items oi
JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id
GROUP BY p.category
ORDER BY revenue DESC
"}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Product performance metrics", "sql": "
SELECT 
  p.name AS product,
  p.category,
  p.price AS list_price,
  ROUND(AVG(oi.unit_price), 2) AS avg_selling_price,
  SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) AS revenue,
  SUM(oi.quantity) AS units_sold,
  COUNT(DISTINCT oi.order_id) AS orders,
  ROUND(SUM(oi.quantity * oi.unit_price) * 1.0 / COUNT(DISTINCT oi.order_id), 2) AS revenue_per_order
FROM order_items oi
JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id
GROUP BY p.id, p.name, p.category, p.price
ORDER BY revenue DESC
LIMIT 100
"}
function.name: sql_query

function.arguments:
{"title": "Bottom performers", "sql": "

FROM order_items oi
JOIN products p ON oi.product_id = p.id
GROUP BY p.id, p.name, p.category
ORDER BY revenue ASC
LIMIT 10
"}

### Key insights
Hardware products deliver the highest revenue per order ($344 average), while Accessories struggle with low average order value ($54). Gadgets balance volume and value effectively. Consider bundling or discontinuing the weakest Accessories, and invest marketing in high-margin Services and Hardware lines.

**Focus on Services and Hardware for maximum revenue impact, and reassess the Accessories portfolio for profitability.**
